name: Nelson Creek
description:
Be aware: Nelson Creek is on private land. Please see Red Tape before running this creek.

A nice short (few hours) objective -- possibly one that can be combined with other outings in the area. Nelson Creek seems to sport good flow early in the season, but reduces to a trickle in late August. Expect some swimming. Nelson culminates with a swim through a 300ft long tunnel.

  • For a longer adventure, consider combining Nelson with Souther Creek next door.

Approach

Directions: Lower Trailhead

From Bridge of the Gods, go east on Hwy 14. Follow Hwy 14 for 3.9mi, passing through the town of Stevenson to locate a large pullout on the right/south side of the road. It is the first pullout just past the Stevenson Cemetary. The pullout is just across from "Passage Way" - a private drive.

Directions: Upper Trailhead

Either walk or shuttle to the upper trailhead. Use caution if walking along Hwy 14 as cars come barreling along at high speeds. Follow Hwy 14 east for 0.3mi, before turning left onto much quieter Nelson Creek Rd. Follow the winding road upwards for 0.5mi, keeping an eye out left for a guard-rail. One can either park in a pullout immediately before the guardrail or continue ahead 100ft to a much larger pullout across the street from a private residence. Total hike time: 15min.

Please respect the locals and drop down into the creek before donning wetsuits.

Dropping In

From the upper parking area, walk north up the road. On passing the driveway to the private home on your right, watch carefully on the left side for a dirty trail disappearing downwards into the bushes. Keep a close eye out as it's not immediately obvious. Follow the trail steeply downwards and you'll drop right in on what looks like a makeshift water collection station with a small working electric pump. The pump likely serves one of the local residences, so touch nothing.

Walk downstream all of 2min to the top of R1.

Descent

  • R1: Nelson Falls - 75ft. Rappel from large boulder DCL. In low water, land on a ledge at the edge of the plunge-pool. Either drop into the pool or edge DCL to avoid the swim. In higher water you may want to use a tree higher up DCR to stay out of the flow.
  • R2: 12ft. Rappel or carefully downclimb (?) DCR.

Below R2, stay DCL and scramble through house-sized boulders for 200ft. Watch for a big tree DCL which marks a possible exit: a dirt trail that switchbacks steeply upwards to the road. Beware poison oak along the escape route.

  • 15ft ramp.
  • 30ft ramp.
  • R3: 25ft into a pool.

Head downstream about 5-10min. It can be thrashy depending on the season. Stay in the creek all the way to then end to find a giant culvert passing underneath Hwy 14 and the RR tracks. The tunnel is huge; people have kayaked through it before when the river is high enough. Wade or swim the tunnel out into the Columbia River - an amusing finale to Nelson Creek. Headlamp unnecessary during the daylight hours.

Exit

Once through the tunnel bear west (DCR) along the shore a 100yrds and then climb out on the rocks wherever is easiest. Make your way up a steep bank, cross the RR tracks to your waiting car. While clearly fishermen frequent the shore here from time to time, be aware that walking on the tracks is trespassing, so make the crossing short & sweet. Freight trains come barreling through here at 60mph with little-to-no warning, so this is not a good place to linger or go for a walk.

Staging Area

Changing out of wetsuits right along Hwy 14 is not recommended. Instead of giving the neighbors and passing drivers a show, head west on Hwy 14 about 0.8mi to Stevenson. At the west end of town where the main road diverges from the business route, turn off immediately left on an unsigned road toward Sailboard Park. The road become dirt briefly, crosses a small creek, then goes under the RR tracks. Once under the bridge, look for a large pullout on your right and a pedestrian bridge/walkway on your left. Park here and walk in to a largely unsigned hidden picnic area which makes for a much better place to change. Nice views of the river here and good place to relax and enjoy a post-canyon festive beverage. Drive-time: ~2 minutes.

Red tape

Update: Aug 28, 2017
A group running the creek had an encounter with a local homeowner who indicated that Nelson Falls is actually on private land and that they prefer folks to check in with them before running the creek per liability concerns. Previously (per the NW Waterfall Survey) it was believed that Nelson was on public land, but after a closer examination of land parcels in [http:

//skamaniawa.mapsifter.com/defaultHTML5.aspx Skamania County] it appears Nelson is indeed private. It would be best to not run this creek without first getting permission from the land owners.  :(

Beta sites

Trip reports and media

Background

Several very old ropes were found at several of the lower falls indicating this creek has seen previous visitors. There was no sign of recent visitation in visiting in July 2017.
